intro: Phalacrocarpus, commonly known as the mangrove fern, is a genus of flowering plants belonging to the family Araliaceae. It is characterized by its woody structure and ability to thrive in saline and waterlogged soils, making it a common inhabitant of coastal and estuarine environments. The plant typically features compound leaves with a variety of leaflet arrangements, and its flowers are small and clustered. Phalacrocarpus species are often found in tropical and subtropical regions, contributing to the ecological diversity of mangrove ecosystems. These plants play a vital role in stabilizing shorelines and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial organisms.
